column1: #Text=Two stolen alabaster duck vessels returned to Egypt in 2008 , one from Christie ’ s In 2008 , two alabaster vessels in the form of trussed ducks were returned to Egypt ( SCA nd ) .
#Text=They had been officially excavated in 1979 from a burial chamber in the pyramid complex of the 12th Dynasty pharaoh Amenemhat III at Dashur , and stolen from storage in Saqqara sometime later .
#Text=In 2006 , Christie ’ s New York brought one of the ducks to the attention of a curator at the Metropolitan Museum of Art ( who was ironically the artefact ’ s excavator ) .
#Text=It was advertised as lot 171 in the Christie ’ s 16 June 2006 Antiquities catalogue , described as an Egyptian alabaster vessel , with an estimated price of $ 20,000–30,000 USD .
#Text=The provenance was said to be an Israeli private collection , acquired prior to 1975 .
#Text=The Metropolitan ’ s curator alerted the Egyptian Supreme Council of Antiquities .
#Text=Christie ’ s withdrew the piece from sale , allowing US Customs and Immigration to obtain a seizure warrant prior to its return to Egypt .
#Text=The identity of the consignor was not revealed .
#Text=The second duck was recognized in the possession of London-based dealer Rupert Wace , who returned it to its previous owner in Paris , the auction company PIASA .
#Text=PIASA then returned the piece to Egypt ( SCA nd ) .
#Text=( Image via the Supreme Council of Antiquities and Rupert Wace Gallery )
